metadata.sermon_start_end: Last week I read in the Times that in one single day — one 24-hour period — the “Deep Blue” Website received 22 million hits. Twenty-two million! I must admit that I was staggered by that. [...] May you be granted such an abundance of gifts that, through you, Christ our Lord may yet do such great things with this congregation that we cannot presently even imagine them, by the great might of his Holy Spirit. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on one specific pericope. It functions as a thematic speech on the Holy Spirit, jumping between Genesis, the Gospel of John, and 1 Corinthians. It treats the Bible as a source of keywords rather than a specific, unique word of God for the moment.
quotes: I think you will recognize it: 'In the beginning God created...'
Jesus himself said so, in the Gospel of John...
Please turn to the Epistle lesson from I Corinthians (12:4-13)...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the 1 Corinthians 2 or 12 passage and extract what is unique to that specific text that cannot be found in the other cited passages.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial. While the preacher mentions the Greek word 'apostolos', there is no rigorous engagement with the historical context of the Corinthian or Johannine communities. The preacher relies on systematic definitions rather than historical-critical exposition.
quotes: The word apostolos, in Greek, means 'one who is sent.'
The Holy Spirit is the third person of the Trinity — 'proceeding from the Father and the Son' as we say in the Nicene Creed.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond dictionary definitions of Greek words and explain the specific theological crisis in Corinth that Paul was addressing with these words.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete regarding the local parish (St. John's) and the 'Deep Blue' website, but it often lapses into generalities about 'spirit' and 'gifts' without defining the specific ethical or political demands of the text.
quotes: What is any of that compared to 22 million people logging on to just one site on the Internet...
If it never happened, we should shut down St. John’s this very day...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid generalities like 'power for life' or 'power for service' and specify what the 'apostolic flame' demands of the Salisbury congregation in 1997.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of thematic reflections. Exposition and application are not 'mixed' in a way that the hearer is 'expounded' by the text; rather, the text is used to illustrate the preacher's points about the Spirit.
quotes: Another fashion in describing the Holy Spirit is to liken him to school spirit...
I wonder if you noticed anything strange a few moments ago. I said 'What is the Holy Spirit...'
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the movement of the biblical text dictate the movement of the sermon, rather than using the text as a 'biblical insert' to support a topical lecture.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Redemption is present, and gratitude is hinted at through 'gifts'. However, 'misery' is largely absent or minimized to a feeling of 'foolishness' compared to the internet. The depth of human lostness before God is not the background of this sermon.
quotes: For a few minutes I felt very foolish and small.
They were the most ordinary people in the world until the Holy Spirit got hold of them.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The preacher should address the 'misery' of a church or individual without the Spirit more sharply, beyond just being 'ordinary' or 'insignificant'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the possibility of the faith being a 'fraud' and the church being 'converted to secular use,' which touches on temporal loss. However, the ultimate seriousness of the 'two ways' (life vs. destruction) is softened by a focus on 'gifts' and 'common good'.
quotes: If the church isn’t apostolic, then the entire Christian faith... is a fraud from beginning to end.
The broad way that leads to destruction [is missing; the sermon focuses on the 'apostolic flame' as a given].
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher must present the choice of the 'narrow way' as a matter of life and death, rather than just a matter of church vitality.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. The preacher correctly identifies Christ as the telos and insists on the personal nature of the Spirit as the 'living presence of Jesus'. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit.
quotes: The Holy Spirit is the living, personal Spirit of Jesus...
He will take what is mine and declare it to you.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that Christ as the 'telos' leads to a specific word of grace that detaches the hearer from themselves, rather than just 'building them up'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14 minutes (1450 words), the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth'. It covers too many texts too quickly.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the duration to at least 20 minutes by deepening the exegesis of a single passage and exploring its implications more broadly.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily due to its thematic, multi-textual approach and insufficient length. It functions more as a theological lecture on the Holy Spirit than an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' While it is strongly Christocentric and avoids the trap of 'school spirit' metaphors, it lacks the exegetical depth and the existential weight of the 'two ways' that Dekker demands.
strengths: Strong Christological focus, identifying the Spirit as the personal presence of Christ.
Effective rejection of modern 'liberal' reductions of the Spirit to mere 'team spirit' or 'duende'.
Clear attempt to connect the liturgical moment (Pentecost) with the congregational life.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific biblical pericope as the foundation.
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold for depth.
Exegesis is replaced by systematic theological assertions and dictionary definitions.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s definition, this is not a sermon but a thematic speech. It lacks the specificity of 'this text' and the necessary breadth of 20 minutes to achieve homiletical depth.
